dc:title: Factors affecting fruit-set in telopea speciosissima (Proteaceae): The importance of pollen limitation
dc:creator: Whelan R.
dc:description: (1) This study examined whether or not receipt of out-cross pollen limited reproductive success in the Australian proteaceous shrub Telopea speciosissima. (2) Exclusion of pollinators from inflorescences and self-pollination by hand (using whole-plant treatments) produced no fruit, indicating self-incompatibility. (3) Experimental cross-pollination of all flowers on a sample of plants also left exposed to natural pollinators resulted in significantly greater fruit- and seed-set than in open- pollinated, control plants. (4) Hand-pollinated plants produced fruits on 91% of inflorescences compared to 52% for control plants. Mean numbers of fruits plant- I were 9 5 for controls and 22 3 for hand- pollinated plants, producing a mean of 133 seeds plant-1 for control plants and 352 for hand-pollinated plants. (5) Fruit-set was extremely low even after hand-pollination (only 2 9% of flowers produced fruits), so although ineffective pollination did limit fruit-set it is insufficient to explain the low fruit: flower ratio in this species. (6) The number of fruits produced per plant, on unmanipulated plants, did not increase significantly with increasing numbers of inflorescences. There was a significant positive correlation for hand-pollinated plants, suggesting that plants with many inflorescences suffered greater pollination-limitation of fruit-set than those with few.

dc:title: Temporal and spatial variation in the phenology of flowering and fruiting in a tropical rainforest
dc:creator: Heideman P.
dc:description: In submontane rainforest on Negros Island, C Philippines, temporal variation in the percentage of plants in flower or fruit was generally less than 2-fold. Temporal variation in abundance of flowers or fruits was up to 4-fold among some months. A peak in flowering during the dry season and early part of the wet season was due to temporal variation in flowering patterns of trees and palms, but not vines. The long-term relationship of rainfall to phenological patterns remains uncertain. -from Author

dc:title: Regeneration and establishment strategies of emergent macrophytes
dc:creator: Shipley B.
dc:description: The covariation within, and the relationship between 7 juvenile (seed/seedling) and 13 adult traits of 25 species of emergent macrophytes occurring along the Ottawa River, Canada, is described. Contrary to r-K selection, but in accordance with C-S-R theory, there was no association between these 2 sets of traits. The major axis of variation within the juvenile traits consisted, at one end, of large, slowly germinating seeds with seedlings possessing a low relative growth rate, and at the other end of small, rapidly germinating seeds with seedlings possessing a high relative growth rate. The regeneration strategies of these species are interpreted as consisting of fugitive vs. stress-tolerant juveniles. Adult traits showed 2 major trends. The largest was associated with the ability to occupy space and consisted of correlated variation in above-ground biomass, canopy diameter, rhizome thickness and rhizome or stolon length; this trend is interpreted as consisting of fugitive vs. competitive adults. A subordinate trend consisted of an uncoupling of height from above-ground biomass and was associated with the "leafless' morphology of a subset of species; this trend was related to environments in deeper water but having infertile soil and was interpreted as a stress-tolerant strategy. These trends in trait variation were related to environmental gradients of soil fertility and water depth. -Author

dc:title: Effect of nurse plants on the microhabitat and growth of cacti
dc:creator: Franco A.
dc:description: Seedlings of the cactus Carnegiea gigantea at 2 sites in the Sonoran Desert were found only in sheltered microhabitats, 89% occurring under the canopy of Ambrosia deltoidea and Cercidium microphyllum. In contrast, 29% of the seedlings of Ferocactus acanthodes, which tolerates higher temperatures than C. gigantea, occurred in unsheltered microhabitats, where maximum soil surface temperatures reached 71Â°C. Most (70%) of the sheltered seedlings of F. acanthodes occurred under the canopy of the perennial bunchgrass Hilaria rigida. Nurse plants facilitate seedling establishment by reducing high temperatures near the soil surface and provide a microhabitat with a higher soil N level, but shading and competition for water with the nurse plants markedly reduce seedling growth. -from Authors

dc:title: Demographic studies of a dioecious tree. I. Colonization, sex and age structure of a population of Salix cinerea
dc:creator: Alliende M.C.
dc:description: The distribution of individuals of Salix cinerea was mapped in a site in Anglesey, N. Wales. Colonization of the study site apparently began when 2 female trees became established before 1967. The population increased rapidly until 1980, after which few new individuals became established and these were restricted to a few small areas on the site. The overall sex ration was female biased, with a radio of 2:1. The sex ratio of each age cohort was also female biased, except at age 6. There was no evidence of spatial segregation of the sexes, but juvenile plants tended to be spatially segregated from adults. Nearest-neighbour distance was the density measure best correlated with plant performance. Measures of plant growth were more strongly correlated with measures of density in female and juvenile plants than in males. (see also 90/07137). -from Authors

dc:title: Historical records of climate-related growth in Cassiope tetragona from the Arctic
dc:creator: Callaghan T.V.
dc:description: This evergreen species retained up to 232 leaves per shoot. Leaf lengths, plotted against leaf position on the shoots, revealed 1) more or less regular waves caused by the alternation of short spring and autumn leaves with long summer leaves, and 2) an ontogenetic trend represented by a general increase in leaf length with increasing distance between the point of origin of the leaf and the origin of the shoot. The seasonal trend of leaf length was used to delimit annual complements of leaves, of which up to 20 persisted. Correlation analysis between 4 measures of annual leaf performance showed several similarities between 2 Svalbard populations, a few between the low altitude population from Svalbard and that from Swedish Lapland and none between the higher altitude Svalbard population and that from Swedish Lapland. July temperatures and precipitation during May were particularly important for leaf development in the Svalbard populations. In Swedish Lapland, number of leaves per year was correlated with summer temperatures but only negatively with precipitation. At the Swedish site, protection of leaf primordia from frost is probably greater than in Svalbard because of a more persistent snow cover. Correlations between number of leaves per year and the other measures of leaf performance and weather in the previous year were particularly strong in the Svalbard populations, demonstrating the performation of an annual leaf complement by the High Arctic Svalbard populations. This may be an important mechanism to buffer production against particularly adverse weather conditions during the growing season. Retrospective analysis of the historical records of growth preserved in ungrazed herbaceous material from the Arctic can lead to the dating of specific events and the construction of models of long-term climate-related growth. -from Authors

dc:title: The seed regeneration dynamics of an emergent salt marsh
dc:creator: Hutchings M.
dc:description: No seed production was recorded for several species occurring in the established vegetation of the 3 sites examined at Hayling Island, Sussex. Greatest seed output on the high site was by Juncus gerardi, the 7th most abundant species in the vegetation. On the middle site, highest seed output was by Plantago maritima, the 2nd most abundant species. On the low site, the most abundant species, Puccinellia maritima, had the greatest seed output. Total seed output ranged from 20 000m-2 on the high site to 11 000m-2 on the low site. Viability of seeds produced by most species was >80%. There were marked differences in the timing of ripe seed production by different species. A higher proportion of the seed output appeared in the seed bank for species with seeds ripening in summer than for those with seeds ripening in autumn. Large numbers of seeds were recovered from the soil for 6 species. Apart from Puccinellia on the low site, all the halophytes that were efficiently sampled had transient seed banks on all sites. All were Type II (spring germinating), except for Puccinellia on the high and middle sites and Armeria maritima. These had transient Type I (winter germinating) seed banks. Three small-seeded species (J. gerardi, Inula crithmoides, Spergularia marina) were not efficiently sampled from the soil; they are more likely to have persistent seed banks. Maximum seed bank size was 4.4 times greater on the low site than on the high site. Generally, species showed their highest levels of germination and seeding survival on sites where they had their highest percentage cover and seed production. Seedling survival was low except for Aster tripolium and I. crithmoides on the high site and for the annual Suaeda maritima on the low site. -from Authors

dc:title: Plasticity and light interception by six bryophytes of contrasted ecology
dc:creator: Rincon E.
dc:description: Responses were consistent with the hypothesis that in plants of relatively productive habitats, high morphological plasticity in the rate and direction of shoot proliferation function as a "foraging' mechanism which allows resource acquisition in circumstances of localized resource depletion created by the activity of competing neighbours. In bryophytes of shaded and chronically unproductive habitats, plasticity was less pronounced; here the capacity to exploit sunflecks was important. -from Authors

dc:title: Causes of the species-area relation: a study of islands in Lake Manapouri, New Zealand
dc:creator: Kelly B.
dc:description: In an attempt to test the Equilibrium hypothesis, 23 islands in Lake Manapouri were sampled for richness of vascular plant species. Sampling was restricted to beech forest and manuka scrub and was with a fixed-size quadrat (100m2). The percentage of variation in species richness explained by island area was reduced from the 92% found in an earlier study by whole-island sampling to 17% and 10%, respectively. The overall manuka scrub relation showed a significant quadratic relation, and examination of species-area relations within subgroups of quadrats selected for greater habitat uniformity showed one significant linear regression. Possible explanations, not normally considered in species-area studies, are the Incidence Function hypothesis, the Small Island Effect hypothesis, and the Small Island Habitat hypothesis<>9d\that there are inevitable habitat differences between small and large islands. -from Authors

dc:title: Above-ground nutrient turnover and net primary production of an evergreen and a deciduous species in a heathland ecosystem
dc:creator: Aerts R.
dc:description: Above-ground nutrient turnover and net primary production (NPP) in adjacent wet heathland communities dominated by the evergreen dwarfshrub Erica tetralix and the deciduous perennial grass Molinia caerulea were studied in The Netherlands. The evergreen achieved a high NPP in March-May, which accounted for 28% of total annual NPP. There was no NPP in October-March. Secondary thickness growth accounted for 31-49% of NPP in the evergreen. The growing season of the deciduous species lasted from April-September. Above-ground NPP was 2.1-2.6 times higher than that of the evergreen. Leaf litter production by the evergreen only occurred during the summer. Leaf litter production of Molinia occurred in autumn. Leaf expectancy of the leaves was 3 times as high in the evergreen compared with the deciduous species. The evergreen reduced nutrient losses mainly by leaf longevity, a relatively low allocation of nutrients to the leaves and low tisuse nutrient concentrations. The deciduous species reduced nutrient losses mainly by a very effficent retranslocation of nutrients from senescing tissues. Retention of nutrients was greater and NPP was smaller in the evergreen shrub. There is probably a trade-off between these 2 characteristics. Differences in nutrient turnover and productivity may explain the replacement of Erica by Molinia in wet heathlands when nutrient availability increases. -from Authors

dc:title: Ecological studies on Gunung Silam, a small ultrabasic mountain in Sabah, Malaysia. II. Some forest processes
dc:creator: Proctor J.
dc:description: Herbivory (percentage area missing from large numbers of leaf samples of several species) in four plots was: 7.6% (330 m), 6.8% (610 m), 6.9% (790 m) and 7.1% (870 m). Annual mortality of trees (â¥10 cm dbh) was 0.025 (280 m), 0.012 (330 m), 0.015 (410 m), 0.011 (480 m), 0.008 (540 m), 0.011 (610 m), 0.008 (700 m), 0.008 (790 m), 0.010 (790 m) and 0.016 (870 m). Median diameter increment of tree boles was (mm year-1): 1.56 (280 m), 1.13 (330 m), 1.31 (480 m), 0.93 (610 m), 0.91 (790 m) and 0.77 (870 m). Small litter fall was (t ha-1 year-1): 6.51 (280 m), 7.37 (330 m), 5.22 (480 m), 5.60 (610 m), 5.53 (790 m) and 4.80 (870 m). Chemical analyses of a small litter fall showed a number of important features, including an excess of Ca concentrations over Ma concentrations and relatively high concentrations of Ni. Three species rooted in ultrabasic soil have an ability to grow at low foliar nutrient concentrations. Shorea tenuiramulosa (Dipterocarpaceae) appeared to accumulate Ni and had up to 1.0 mg-1 Ni in its leaf dry matter. An unidentified Eugenia species (Myrtaceae) had 13.7 mg g-1 foliar Mn. -from Authors

dc:title: A model of the phosphorus dynamics of Calluna heathland
dc:creator: Chapman S.
dc:description: A computer model of the phosphorus and organic matter relationships within a dry ungrazed Calluna vulgaris heathland from S England is described. The model is used to simulate the development of dune-heath and Calluna heathland. Important features of the model are examined. In particular the importance of the P adsorption capacity of soil is discussed in relation to behaviour of heathland vegetation in different area. The model is used to examine possible consequences of management techniques. -from Authors

dc:title: The growth, distribution and neighbour relationships of Trifolium repens in a permanent pasture. V. The coevolution of competitors
dc:creator: Turkington R.
dc:description: Ramets of Trifolium repens were sampled from sites dominated by Agrostis capillaris, Holcus lanatus and Lolium perenne within a permanent pasture. After multiplication of the ramets, they were transplanted, or replanted, into each of the original sites in all 9 combinations of site of origin and transplant site. The pasture population of T. repens had diverged into a number of subpopulations based on the identity of the grass neighbour. Each T. repens replants grew better in its site of origin than did transplants into that site, interpreted as evidence that population divergence is due to interspecific competition with the dominant grasses. The home-site advantage to T. repens disappears when the grasses are removed. -from Author

dc:title: Seedling mortality in Mimosa pigra, an invasive tropical shrub
dc:creator: Lonsdale W.
dc:description: In a dense thicket on the sloping bank of a lagoon in the tropical Northern Territory, Australia, most Mimosa pigra germination occurred at the start of the dry season, from seeds falling from the canopy on to moist bare soil exposed as the flood water retreated. The earliest cohort emerged at the top of the slope, and last cohort at the bottom. Death rate during the ensuing dry season was lowest in the earliest cohort, greatest in the cohort in the middle of the slope. No seedlings survived the flooding of the following wet season. Survival was density-independent, except at the first sampling date, c2wk after emergency. Removal of the canopy had no significant effect on the probability of seedling survival; artificial shade enhanced survival, as did irrigation. Seedling survival was determined by the availability of soil moisture. The massive expansion of the Australian range of M. pigra that occurred in the late 1970s can probably be attributed to prolific seed production, coupled with episodic recruitment resulting from unusual rainfall patterns. -from Authors

dc:title: Vegetation and land-use history at Diss, Norfolk, UK
dc:creator: Peglar S.
dc:description: In the early stages of sediment deposition in the mere (Devensian late-glacial), Betula woodland covered the landscape. Initially the woodland was open, containing a variety of herbaceous taxa, but later a more closed canopy developed. Betula was replaced primarily by Corylus, which spread rapidly into East Anglia early in the Holocene. Pinus was then probably absent locally, in contrast to sites nearby. The Corylus woodlands gave way to mixed-deciduous forests containing Tilia, Ulmus, Quercus, Corylus and Fraxinus, with Alnus in moist areas. Possible anthropogenic influence on the vegetation is first recorded soon after the development of these mixed deciduous forests. Neolithic people may have made clearings, but these were apparently soon abandoned and recolonized by Corylus. Ulmus populations were permanently affected by these early disturbances, never fully recovering their former abundance. Coincident with these first disturbances was the expansion of Taxus, which became locally abundant, perhaps expanding in woodland openings. Forest clearance, including the selective cutting of Tilia and the cultivation of Hordeum and other cereals, indicates the local presence of prehistoric (Bronze Age) settlements in the catchment. The most marked cultural effect on catchment vegetation was the complete clearance of the forest and the conversion of cleared land to agricultural use in the Iron Age. -from Authors

dc:title: The growth, distribution and neighbour relationships of Trifolium repens in a permanent pasture. VI. Conditioning effects by neighbours
dc:creator: Turkington R.
dc:description: Clones of Trifolium repens were collected from patches dominated by Agrostis capillaris, Holcus lanatus and Lolium perenne in an old permanent pasture. The clones were multiplied and then subjected to repeated cloning in glasshouse conditions, repeated cutting (but not cloning) in boxes outdoors, or transplanting into the original pasture. Newly collected T. repens showed significant among-grass-neighbour patterns of differentiation for five out of 8 morphological characters. Clones from Holcus-dominated sites were largest and those from Agrostis-dominated sites smallest. For clones transplanted into the pasture, shorter conditioning periods in the pasture lead to fewer among-subpopulation differences. -from Author

dc:title: Early post-felling response of Marquesia woodland to burning in the Zambian copperbelt
dc:creator: Chidumayo E.
dc:description: Regeneration was largely of seedling origin but because stumps and roots of cut trees bore multiple stems, regeneration from trunk- and root-suckers dominated stem populations in the coppiced plots. Although stem mortality differed significantly under different cutting treatments it was generally much higher in late- than in early-burnt plots. Although the population of dead stems was dominated by Albizia adianthifolia, Baphia bequaertii and Marquesia macroura, only A. adianthifolia and M. macroura appeared to be less fire-tolerant. -from Author

dc:title: Clonal growth of Salix setchelliana on glacial river gravel bars in Alaska
dc:creator: Douglas D.
dc:description: Salix setchelliana is a prostrate clonal willow that grows peripherally from a horizontal root system. Vertical shoots are typically 5-20 cm tall. Growth and demography of shoots and clones were examined in Denali National Park, Alaska, and have been related to the transitory gravel bar habitat. Shoot emergence and death rates, measured along 2 river systems, did not show significant year to year variability, but were affected by position within a clone. Shoot death, but not shoot emergence, differed between the patches sampled. Shoot survivorship curves are log linear. Patch survivorship, measured in one river system, averaged 95% per yr-1. Clonal expansion rates averaged 0.25 and 0.19 m yr-1 at the two locations examined. Clones vary in their percentage of expanding versus non-expanding edges; the non-expanding edges are associated with old channels banks or gravel with large rocks and large shrubs. Clonal segments broken off by migrating river channels appear to be able to serve as long-distance propagules. S. setchelliana exhibits rapid radial spread, reducing the likelihood of genet extinction in its transitory habitat. -Author

dc:title: Species interactions in a successional grassland. III. Effects of canopy gaps, gopher mounds and grazing on colonization
dc:creator: Peart D.
dc:description: Species' ability to colonize canopy gaps and gopher mounds were assessed in a Californian grassland, with seed introduction experiments, for the 5 most cover-dominant grass species: Anthoxanthum odoratum, Holcus lanatus, Deschampsia holciformis, Rytidosperma pilosum (all perennial bunchgrasses) and Vulpia bromoides (an annual grass). Formation of canopy gaps by the death of individual bunchgrasses and soil disturbances by gophers strongly affected colonization success. The best colonizers were Anthoxanthum and Holcus, whose colonization success was increased 6-2500-fold by canopy gap formation, and 10-200-fold by the formation of gopher mounds. Few, small seedlings of Deschampsia and Rytidosperma survived in canopy gaps or on gopher mounds. Deschampsia and Rytidosperma did not reproduce in gaps or on mounds over a 2-yr period. Vulpia colonists had higher seed production on mounds than the 4 perennials. Vulpia also colonized canopy gaps, but was excluded by perennial vegetation in the 2nd year of growth in the gaps. In annual-dominated vegetation, neither aboveground biomass nor colonization by Anthoxanthum was affected by excluding grazers, but exclusion of grazers led to an increase in the cover of forbs after two years. Clipping aboveground vegetation allowed Rytidosperma to achieve dominance in sites where, under undisturbed conditions, it existed only as a suppressed understorey. All other perennials were negatively affected by clipping. The species with the highest natural densities of seed rain also had the greatest per-seed colonization success, even though negative density-dependent effects must have been strongest for those species. Seed size was positively correlated with survivorship on mounds, but was unrelated to the sizes of individual colonists in gaps or on mounds. Overall, canopy gaps and gopher mounds favoured the same species that colonized well in undisturbed sites. Both types of disturbance increased colonization by perennials in annual-dominated vegetation, and canopy gaps were required for changes in species dominance in perennial vegetation. -from Author

dc:title: Modelling the population dynamics of an annual plant Sorghum intrans in the wet-dry tropics
dc:creator: Watkinson A.
dc:description: Sorghum intrans dominates the understorey of the savanna woodlands in the wet-dry tropics of NW Australia. Abundance is determined primarily by an interaction between the negatively density-dependent control of fecundity and various sources of density-independent mortality. In areas of poor growth potential, fecundity of Sorghum is considerably reduced and density of plants is very low. Populations would not be able to persist in these regions were it not for migration of seeds into them from the surrounding areas favourable for Sorghum growth. In the short term, an annual dry season fire will reduce density of flowering Sorghum plants by c40%; a rainy season fire, following seedling emergence, has the potential to eliminate populations completely, because Sorghum lacks a persistent seed bank. A high density of the seed-harvesting ant Meranoplus can reduce the density of Sorghum by an order of magnitude. The ants show a Type 2 functional response to the density of seeds. -from Authors

dc:title: Seasonal variation in flowering intensity and pollination limitation of fruit set in four co-occurring Banksia species
dc:creator: Copland B.
dc:description: In SE Australia, mean numbers of inflorescences per plant varied markedly between years, but timing of onset, park and completion of flowering was relatively consistent among years for all species (Banksia ericifolia, B. paludosa, B. serrata, B. spinulosa). Three of the 4 species studied flowered in winter; flowering times for these 3 overlapped substantially. Fruit set in the 3 winter-flowering species varied both within and between years. Variation was caused by differences in the proportions of inflorescences successfully setting fruit and not by differences in numbers of fruits produced per inflorescence. Fruit set in B. ericifolia was examined in detail. The proportion of inflorescences setting fruit was generally lower in late-season samples. Resource limitation probably explained this. Pollination was limiting fruit set in 1985. Interspecific competition among plants for pollination may be occurring. About half of the inflorescences produced by the B. ericifolia plants studied over 4 study years appeared during peak flowering in 1985. The greatest contribution to the seed bank, which is stored in the canopy until released by a future fire, therefore occurred at this time. -from Authors

dc:title: Influence of insect herbivory on photosynthetic area and reproduction in Gutierrezia species
dc:creator: Wisdom C.
dc:description: Larvae of 2 tortricid lepidopterans, Synnoma lynosyrana and Synalocha gutierreziae, form silk cases that tie together a significant proportion of the photosynthetic stems and leaves of the common rangeland perennial, Gutierrezia sarothrae, which are toxic to cattle. These insects were significantly more abundant in cattle-grazed plots than in ungrazed plots of the Sevilleta National Wildlife Refuge, located in central New Mexico. Measurements were made of photosynthetic area and proximate reproduction of plants with both tied and control (non-tied) branches. In within-plant comparisons, tied branches had significantly less photosynthetic area than control branches. Number of flowers/branch, flowers/capitulum, seeds/branch and seeds/capitulum were all significantly greater for control than for tied branches. However, seeds produced by tied branches germinated more rapidly and at a higher percentage than seeds from control branches over the same time period. Onset of senescence occurred on smaller volume plants in the ungrazed, high larval abundance plots than in the grazed, low larval abundance plots. -from Authors

dc:title: Patterns of night-time respiration in a dense phytoplankton community under a natural light regime
dc:creator: Markager S.
dc:description: Ponds had a dense green algal community (c.500 Î¼g l-1 chlorophyll a) which is believed to be responsible for the majority of community respiration. From August-October 1984, significant changes in respiration rate were found during the night. The most common pattern showed a pronounced peak in respiration rate shortly after sunset, then a gradual decrease during the night and a slight increase before sunrise. Deviation from this pattern was mainly observed during a period with falling daylight and falling algal growth rate. An exponential decrease in respiration rate shows agreement with a physiological model, which assumes that the respiration rate is regulated by a storage pool of carbohydrates built-up by photosynthesis during the previous day. -from Authors

dc:title: An analysis of seasonal patterns of bryophyte growth in a natural habitat
dc:creator: Rincon E.
dc:description: Seasonal patterns of growth of 5 bryophyte species were investigated in an area of N-facing calcareous grassland in N Derbyshire. Simultaneous measurements of dry weight and shoot length were possibly by the use of a new experimental field technique. Marked differences in relative growth rate occurred between the species and uncoupling between growth in length and in dry weight was observed. -Authors

dc:title: Stemwood biomass and production during spruce-fir stand development
dc:creator: Aplet G.
dc:description: A 600-yr chronosequence of Engelmann spruce-subalpine fir (Picea engelmannii-Abies lasiocarpa) forest was used to examine the effects of changes in forest structure on stemwood biomass and production in a mixed-species community. Fir size-class and age-class structure stabilized early in stand development, but spruce size and age structure changed throughout stand development. Community stemwood biomass remained nearly constant through time as an increase in spruce biomass compensated for mortality in the fir component. Fir production decreased from initially high levels with change in size-class structure, but spruce production remained nearly constant. Stemwood production was related to leaf area in both species, but patterns of leaf-area allocation differed between species. Constant fir leaf area and production are achieved after stand structure stabilizes, but constant spruce leaf area and production occurred despite changes in stand structure. -Authors

dc:title: Vegetation patterns in spring-fed calcareous fens: calcite precipitation and constraints on fertility
dc:creator: Boyer M.
dc:description: Some spring-fed calcareous fens in Britain have a distinct vegetation pattern, with stands of low-growing species-rich vegetation abruptly joined by taller, less rich vegetation. The short-fen vegetation occupies the main seepage tracks; the taller-fen community, though still irrigated by water seepage, flanks the most active seepage zones. Above-ground crop mass and net productivity were much smaller in short-fen than taller-fen zones. Juncus subnodulosus occurred in both short- and taller-fen zones at most sites, but its shoot mass was much less in the short-fen. Concentration of P in living leaves was also lower in shoots from short-fen zones, whilst concentrations of Ca, Mg, K and N were similar to, or higher than, those in taller-fen living shoots of J. subnodulosus. As P limits short-fen fertility, high NO3- concentrations in groundwater discharge do not increase fertility. The conservationally valuable short-fen vegetation may therefore relate to intrinsic geochemical processes, though the ultimate capacity of the system to immobilize P is not known. -from Authors

dc:title: Competition in mixtures of the annual Hypochoeris glabra and perennial H. radicata
dc:creator: Fone A.
dc:description: Estimates of the effects of interspecific and intraspecific competition, based on rosette, root and reproductive dry weights, showed that the perennial H. radicata (Asteraceae) was similar to the annual H. glabra in ability to compete for resources under the experimental conditions. For annual and perennial Hypochoeris, there was little evidence for an association between life-history and competitive ability, even though the assumption that annuals allocate proportionally more resources to reproduction was valid. -from Author

dc:title: Relations between native and exotic plant guilds in the Upper Clutha, New Zealand
dc:creator: Wilson J.
dc:description: The native and exotic plant guilds produced classifications of the quadrats that were no more different than those using random groups of species, suggesting that the guilds follow the same vegetational boundaries, but there was some evidence that the guilds differ in the environmental factors with which they are correlated. The ratio of the two guilds differed between quadrats, and inverse classification showed significant differences in their distribution. It is concluded that the two guilds differ ecologically. The importance of exotics has steadily increased over the past 50 yr, and is probably still increasing. There was more structure in the native guild than in the exotic guild, even allowing for guild size. The native guild was slighly more related to the environment, but the local community was more related to the exotic guild than to the native guild, an effect that did not seem to be due to guild size. In spite of these differences, the native and exotic guilds now form one community at each point. The exotic guild tends to determine the structure of the community, but it is still invading and therefore not yet at equilibrium. -from Author

dc:title: Dynamics and weight loss of leaf litter in Central Himalayan forests: abiotic versus litter quality influences
dc:creator: Upadhyay V.
dc:description: Litters high in cell wall constituents tend to be lower in nutrient concentrations. Relative patterns of change in K and Ca concentrations tended to differ from those of N, P and Na. Monthly rainfall and could account for 25-89% of monthly weight loss of litter on each site. Annual temperature, actual evapotranspiration (AET) and altitude explained, respectively, 48.7%, 53.6% and 49.1% of variability. Measures of cell wall constituents, eg lignin concentration, could account for up to 60% of the variability in weight loss in the first year; however, lignin, as a predictor of weight loss rate, contains considerable information about plant nutrients. In warm temperate and subtropical climates the cell wall constituents seem to be good predictors of weight loss in the first year while in cool temperature to arctic climates, the early stages of decay are prolonged, resulting in good prediction by litter nutrients. -from Authors

dc:title: Demographic studies of a dioecious tree. II. The distribution of leaf predation within and between trees
dc:creator: Alliende M.
dc:description: The extent of (mainly insect) damage to the leaves of Salix cinerea was determined in a naturally established population in Anglesey, N Wales. Leaves on male trees suffered more damage than those on females or juveniles. Leaves in shaded portions of the canopy suffered more damage, but compass orientation of the branches had no effect. Intensity of flowering had significant though complex effects on the degree of predation suffered by the leaves. (See also 90L/07316). -from Author

dc:title: Plant biomass, species diversity and net primary production in a central Himalayan high altitude grassland
dc:creator: Ram J.
dc:description: The time-series of live shoot biomass exhibited a unimodal growth pattern during each of the 2 yr of study. Peak live shoot biomass, attained in August, ranged between 382-409 g m-2. The relative growth rate of the live shoots ranged between 8-42 mg g-1 day-1, the maximum rate occurring during the early part of the growing season. Rise in temperature which caused the snow-melt in mid-April was followed by vegetation growth. Snow-melt also provided plant-available moisture, and shoot growth began at a rapid rate during April-May. Biomass accumulation was sustained by monsoon rainfall in June-August. Species diversity declined from a maximum in June to a minimum in October. Danthonia cachemyriana showed increasing dominance with advancement of the growing season. Minimum annual net shoot production ranged between 453-527 g m-2, minimum total below-ground net production between 284-449 g m-2. The total dry matter disappearance almost balanced the total net organic matter input within the annual cycle, ie the system is in equilibrium. -from Authors

dc:title: Sulphide as a soil phytotoxin: differential responses in two marsh species
dc:creator: Koch M.
dc:description: Addition of 1.0 mM sulphide resulted in significantly less total biomass of Spartina alterniflora and Panicum hemitomon. Sulphide significantly reduced culm, root and rhizome biomass in P. hemitomon but only root biomass in S. alterniflora. P. hemitomon had no significant difference in total biomass between the aerated and non-aerated treatments, but S. alterniflora total biomass was lower in the aerated treatment than in the non-aerated treatment. Redox potential in the soil cores of both species was highest in the aerated treatment, intermediate in the non-aerated treatment, and lowest in the sulphide treatment. S. alterniflora and P. hemitomon soluble interstitial NH4+ and PO43- concentrations followed an inverse relationship to redox potential and differences between treatments were highly significant. Root Fe concentrations in S. alterniflora were an order of magnitude higher than Fe concentrations in leaves of S. alterniflora and roots and leaves of P. hemitomon. -from Authors

dc:title: Carbon balance of Panicum coloratum during drought and non-drought in the northern Chihuahuan Desert
dc:creator: Sisson W.B.
dc:description: Water stress severely repressed diurnal photosynthetic capacity during drought. Below-ground biomass, however, consisted of suberized roots with low respiratory activity. The net result was a positive whole-plant carbon gain of 2.6 mg C g dry wt-1 day-1. Precipitation (1.12 cm) ended the 52 d drought, and increased the whole-plant carbon gain 6-fold. Mean root/shoot quotient was 1.9 during the spring drought and 0.6 in autumn. Reproductive tissue accounted for 13-34% (mean 22%) of above-ground biomass in autumn. Following reproductive growth, when soil-moisture conditions were favourable, the root system comprised suberized roots, non-suberized nodal roots and other non-suberized roots. Although the last 2 root types had high respiration rates, their presence in low quantities and low soil temperatures resulted in below-ground respiration approximately equal to that during drought. The whole-plant carbon gain during September was 17.2 mg C g dry wt-1 day-1. -from Author

dc:title: Forty years of change in Lady Park Wood: the young-growth stands
dc:creator: Peterken G.
dc:description: Lady Park Wood, Monmouth, is an ancient semi-natural woodland, designated as an unmanaged reserve in 1944. In 1943 part of the wood had been virtually clear-felled, then left to regenerate. Lime (Tilia cordata, T. platyphyllos), beech Fagus sylvatica and hazel Corylus avellana, and in smaller numbers oak Quercus petraea and maple Acer campestre, have regenerated from coppice stools, but most of the regeneration has come from abundant seedlings of birch (Betula pendula, B. pubescens) and ash Fraxinus excelsior, with smaller numbers of sallow Salix caprea, beech, lime, oak and maple. Regeneration was initially patchy: groups of seedlings were interspersed with open areas dominated mainly by Rus fruticosus. By 1955 the canopy was closed and subsequently there has been no effective recruitment. As stands developed there was a rapid decrease in number of stems whilst the canopy initially remained closed. Very few oak samplings survived. A severe drought in 1976 followed by heavy snow in 1981 killed numerous birch and opened many gaps. Beech saplings were subsequently severely damaged by grey squirrels Sciurus carolinensis. The initial birch dominance is thus being irregularly replaced, mainly by coppice growth and ash poles. Mature oaks which were left standing in the cut-over areas, have remained healthy. Many beech, also retained, have died or deteriorated since the 1976 drought. The uneven distribution of tree species regeneration was determined only partly by inherent site factors. Small-scale initial patchiness, due partly to deer browsing, quickly disappeared. The effects of past management will persist. The Initial Floristic Composition model describes the early stages of succession well, but no single model encompasses the whole process. -from Authors

dc:title: New methods for the analysis of spatial pattern in vegetation
dc:creator: Dale M.
dc:description: A new method of analysis is suggested that modifies the interpretation of quadrat variance methods for detecting the scale of spatial pattern in vegetation. A complementary method is presented for distinguishing the contributions made by the sizes of the gaps (regions of low density) and of the patches (regions of high density) to that pattern. Application of these methods to a study of primary succession on proglacial deposits indicates that the scale of pattern does not change with surface age. Growth and coalescence of patches of vegetation may be counterbalanced by their senescence and breakup, and by continued colonization. -from Authors

dc:title: Lesser snow geese and the nitrogen economy of a grazed salt marsh
dc:creator: Bazely D.
dc:description: The acetylene-reduction technique was used to measure nitrogenase activity of surface sediments of a subarctic salt march at Perouse Bay, Manitoba, in order to estimate whether some of the nitrogen of forage plants that is incorporated into body tissues of a herbivore (Chen caerulescens caerulescens) is replaced by N-fixation. Nitrogenase activity was consistently higher in grazed plots compared with rates in ungrazed plots. Estimates of total amounts of N fixed in grazed plots between June and September ("melt to freeze-up') were c1 g N m-2. Unlike ungrazed swards, where plant litter accumulated, mats of cyanobacteria were present on the surface of sediments between individual plants. Levels of exchangeable and soluble ammonium ions were low (eg <6 Î¼g exchangeable N-NH4 g dry wt-1 sediment) throughout most of the growing season, but higher levels were detected in early spring and fall, particularly in grazed plots. Only trace amounts of nitrate ions were present in sediment extracts. A feedback model involving different aspects of the nitrogen cycle describes the strong interaction between the herbivore and salt marsh vegetation. The intense cropping of vegetation results in little accumulation of plant litter. Patches of sediment are colonized by cyanobacteria that maintain the long-term N input. -from Authors

dc:title: Biological flora of the British Isles: Lobelia dortmanna L
dc:creator: Farmer A.M.
dc:description: With reference to water lobelia, describes geographical and altitudinal distribution (which is upland northern and western); habitat; communities; response to biotic factors; gregariousness, performance in various habitats, and effect of frost and drought; morphology, mycorrhiza, perennation, chromosomes and physiological data; phenology; floral biology, hybrids, seed production and dispersal, and seedling morphology; animal feeders, plant parasites and plant diseases; and history. -J.W.Cooper

dc:title: Experimental investigation of bryophyte interactions on a dry heathland
dc:creator: Scandrett E.
dc:description: The pleurocarpous mosses Pleurozium schreberi, Hylocomium splendens and Hypnum jutlandicum typically occur in gaps in degenerate Calluna vulgaris bushes in dry heathland. In monocultures, the 3 species behaved similarly, producing higher yields and displaying greater intraspecific inhibition (as a result of interactions between "individuals' derived from different sown fragments) in shade than in light. Although yields were somewhat higher in dry than in wet conditions, inhibition was greater in the wet. H. jutlandicum showed the most intraspecific inhibition, P. schreberi the least. Most pairs of species produced the highest yields and showed the greatest mutual inhibition in the shade and in dry conditions. H. jutlandicum was the most successful species in mixtures. Its proportional yield was enhanced, while that of each of the other species (especially P. schreberi) was reduced. -from Authors

dc:title: Genet and ramet demography of Oenocarpus mapora ssp. mapora, a clonal palm of Panamanian tropical moist forest
dc:creator: De Steven D.
dc:description: All ramets develop through a fixed sequence of morphological stages; a genet's stage-class is determined by the stage and size of its largest ramet, which defines genet functional status within the population. A genet establishing from seed develops through 2 single-ramet stages (seedling and non-clonal juvenile), followed by 3 clonal stages (clonal juvenile, subadult and reproductive adult). Both ramet growth rates and ramet survivorship increase with ramet size and developmental stage. High within-stage variation in ramet growth suggests tolerance of understorey suppression but opportunistic response to higher light levels. Rates of daughter ramet production by clonal genets average <1 per genet yr-1. A genet appears to produce daughter ramets when environmental conditions also favour vigorous growth and sexual reproduction by existing ramets. In contrast to non-clonal stages, survivorship of clonal genets is very high because treefalls and windthrows, a major mortality factor for all stage-classes, rarely kill all ramets within a genet. Genet flowering frequency increases with adult clone size, and flowering is stimulated by high light levels. A static population structure in the "mature forest' site is evident in its low genet population density, high dominance of large adult clones and poor seedling recruitment. High genet population density, high juvenile dominance and good seedling recruitment in the "disturbed forest' site suggest that O. mapora may be especially favoured in habitats prone to canopy disturbance. -from Author

dc:title: Seed size and number in Rubus chamaemorus: between-habitat variation, and effects of defoliation and supplemental pollination
dc:creator: Agren J.
dc:description: In 8 populations of Rubus chaemaemorus in N Sweden and Finland, seed mass varied 4-fold overall, up to 3-fold within populations, and up to 2-fold within single fruits. Ramets in shaded populations were larger, and produced larger seeds than ramets in open populations, but had a lower total seed-to-leaf mass ratio. Seed number and total seed mass per fruit did not differ consistently between open and shaded populations. Mean seed mass was negatively correlated with seed number per fruit, and with number of seeds per unit leaf and rhizome mass, respectively. Fruits that matured early contained more seeds and had a higher total seed mass than fruits that matured late. Mean seed mass did not vary as strongly between years as did seed number and total seed mass per fruit. Supplemental hand pollination in a shaded population increased seed number and total seed mass per fruit. Defoliation did not influence fruit or seed set, nor total seed mass per fruit. Complete defoliation reduced mean seed mass by 13. Production of larger seeds in the shade may reflect a variation between habitats in the optimal balance between seed number and size. -from Author

dc:title: Variation in competition along an environmental gradient: Hieracium floribundum in an abandoned pasture
dc:creator: Reader R.
dc:description: Rosette survival, recruitment and population growth all increased when neighbours were removed, but only at one end of the gradient (higher standing crop, lower light). Reducing soil moisture at the start of the experiment did not affect rosette survival but it increased rosette recruitment where nutrient and standing crop were higher on the gradient, but recruitment increased whether neighbours were present or absent, so intensity of competition, measured as the difference in recruitment with neighbours present and absent, was not affected by variation in soil moisture availability at either end of the gradient. Results support the proposal that competition should intensify as soil fertility and plant standing crop increase, even when moisture availability also varies. -from Authors

dc:title: Mineral nutrient allocation in seeds and shoots of twelve Chionochloa species in relation to soil fertility
dc:creator: Lee W.G.
dc:description: Shoots and seeds of C. acicularis, C. crassiuscula, C. conspicua, C. flavescens, C. macra, C. oreophila, C. ovata, C. pallens, C. rigida, C. rubra, C. spiralis and C. teretifolia were collected over 5 days in late summer. Tillers were separated into sheaths, green leaves and dead leaf blades. The tiller parts and the seeds were dried, weighed and analysed for N, P, K, Ca, Mg, Fe, S and Na. The order obtained by ranking the species in increasing total mineral concentration of tillers is significantly related to that obtained when the species are ranked in order of increasing fertility of their respective soils as determined in the bioassay. Soil fertility is correlated positively with tiller weight and negatively with seed weight. For all elements measured except Ca the seed enrichment ratio (concentration of element in seed/concentration of same element in shoots) decreases consistently from species with low shoot concentrations to species with high shoot concentrations. The biomass of vegative tillers was lower in flowering tussocks in 3 of the 4 species. Tillers from flowering tussocks had proportionately smaller leaf blades, larger sheaths and more dead leaf blade. Chionochloa species from infertile soils tended to have smaller shoots, lower mineral nutrient concentrations, higher seed enrichment ratios and larger seeds. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of short-lived plants in chalk grassland. III. Population stability
dc:creator: Kelly D.
dc:description: Detailed demographic observations were made on 3 annual hemiparasites (Euphrasia pseudokerneri, E. nemorosa, Rhinanthus minor) and 2 strict biennials (Linum catharticum, Gentianella amarella) at 3 sites spread 150 km apart on the chalk grassland of SE England over 3 yr. Over distances of a few metres within the Fleam Dyke site, Cambridgeshire, there were large differences in seedling density and in survival to flowering for all 3 species present. For E. pseudokerneri and Gentianella, the pattern of seedling densities was constant over time, but the pattern of high and low survival was different in successive years. Linum showed no constant pattern of seedling densities but the pattern of high and low survival was the same for the 1980 and 1981 cohorts (but different for the 1979 and 1980 cohorts). The short-lived plants seem to exist as "shifting clouds' which move slowly around in the turf. For the biennials and E. pseudokerneri, most variation in population size was explained by the seed-to-germination stage; for E. nemorosa and Rhinanthus, survival from germination to flowering, and the number of seeds produced per fruiting plant were the crucial stages. At Fleam Dyke over the study interval, E. pseudokerneri decreased in density 100-fold while Gentianella was constant in numbers; Linum was intermediate. Both life-history parameters (generation time, presence of a seed bank) and sensitivity to environmental factors were implicated in the differences between species. Gentianella was more "stoical' (less sensitive to environmental changes) than Linum, which seemed to be important in the greater constancy of Gentianella. Over widely separated sites Euphrasia spp. behaved in completely opposite ways, while changes in Gentianella were perfectly in parallel at all three sites. -from Author

dc:title: The effects of Puccinia lagenophorae on Senecio vulgaris in competition with Euphorbia peplus
dc:creator: Paul N.
dc:description: Rust-infection greatly reduced S. vulgaris dry weights, especially of the roots, both in monocultures and mixtures but the yields of both control and rusted S. vulgaris were little changed by competition from E. peplus at any planting density. E. peplus yields were greatly reduced by competition from S. vulgaris but less so in the presence of rust, especially at lower planting densities. The magnitude of rust-induced reductions in the yields of S. vulgaris decreased as the proportion of E. peplus in mixtures increased. However, increases in E. peplus yields when S. vulgaris was rusted were unaffected by species proportions. The inequality (skewness) of the dry weight and plant height hierarchies of S. vulgaris increased with population density and rust infection but were not changed by competition from E. peplus. S. vulgaris, whether control or rusted, strongly outcompeted E. peplus even though the root dry weights of the latter were often substantially greater. -from Author

dc:title: Effect of Rhizobium leguminosarum biovar trifolii genotype on specificity between Trifolium repens and Lolium perenne
dc:creator: Chanway C.
dc:description: Compatibility between genotypes of Lolium perenne and Trifolium repens was not apparent when the effect of Rhizobium leguminosarum biovar trifolii was ignored. When genotypes of Lolium and Trifolium that had been neighbours in the field were inoculated, biotic specialization between the pasture plants became evident. The magnitude of the effect, characterized by increased Trifolium yields, could be largely accounted for by the presence of the coexistent Rhizobium-Lolium combinations, regardless of the Trifolium genotype. When Trifolium was inoculated with a mixture of Rhizobium strains, unrelated isolates formed more root nodules than did coexistent ones. When coexistent Rhizobium was administered as a single-strain inoculum, an increased yield of Trifolium was observed. -from Authors

dc:title: A comparative demographic study of annual and perennial Hypochoeris (Asteraceae)
dc:creator: Fone A.
dc:description: In a California coastal grassland, Hypochoeris glabra was an obligate annual, H. radicata a short-lived perennial. Perennials usually reproductive maturity in the 2nd year of life, but survival to this stage was low (<5%). Annuals had much higher maturation rates (19-33%). Yearly survival rates for 1st year perennials and older plants were similar (1-16%). After achieving maturity, perennials flowered each year until death. Annuals and first-year perennials produced an estimated 18 and 13 fruits per plant, respectively, but fruit output for older perennials was c10 times greater than that for 1st year plants. Net reproductive rates for annual and perennial plants were similar (4.4 and 3.0, respectively), indicating similar lifetime fruit production, but a population projection matrix model with hypothetical seed-bank dynamics showed that the annual should have greater finite rates of population growth than the perennial for most combinations of yearly seed mortality and dormancy rate. Elasticity analysis showed that performance of annuals was largely determined by the fraction of new fruit production that germination in the next season. Perennial performance was strongly affected by 1st year plant survival and fruit production in the 2nd year of life, results that were consequences of delayed reproductive maturity. -from Author

dc:title: Photosynthesis and canopy structure of a submerged plant, Potamogeton pectinatus, in a Danish lowland stream
dc:creator: Van Der Bijl L.
dc:description: Basal leaves had lower chlorophyll content and lower photosynthetic efficiency than apical leaves in both low and high light. Potamogeton has an apical growth form leading to increasing age of the tissue with depth in the canopy. The reduced activity of basal leaves can be explained by light limitation and the beginning of senesence. Potamogeton stands concentrated their biomass at the surface surface during summer, thereby compensating for high water attenuation. The photosynthetic rate of the stand was strongly reduced if the biomass was assumed constant with depth. Simultaneously, the depth strata with highest photosynthetic and respiratory activity and the light compensation point in the canopy moved towards the surface. Integrated photosynthesis of the stand showed a hyperbolic dependency on surface photon flux density (PFD). Photosaturation was usually not reached at maximum PFD, due to extensive self-shading. Gross O2 production was primarily regulated by PFD and biomass and showed a unimodal seasonal pattern with maximum in mid-August (7.5 gO2 m-2 day-1). Gross O2 production corresponded to total stream photosynthesis at maximum biomass during mid-summer. Dark respiration was a high proportion of gross photosynthesis, and this proportion increased with biomass and age of tissue during the growing season. Net O2 production increased linearly from early May to early August and was positive until late August. Changes in biomass followed the same seasonal pattern. -from Authors

dc:title: Demography of short-lived plants in chalk grassland. II. Control of mortality and fecundity
dc:creator: Kelly D.
dc:description: Factors affecting germination, survival and reproduction of a hemiparasitic summer annual (Euphrasia pseudokerneri) and 2 strict biennials (Linum catharticum and Gentianella amarella) were examined at 2 chalk grassland sites in SE England. Data are also provided on a 2nd annual (E. nemorosa). Germination of E. pseudokerneri, Linum and Gentianella was restricted to a narrow "window' of germination sites where mean turf height was only 1-3 cm. All 3 species germinated poorly in longer turf, and E. pseudokerneri and Linum also germinated less well in very short areas. Survival of E. pseudokerneri, Linum and Gentianella, and reproductive output of Gentianella, were higher in areas of short turf. Overall, Gentianella was most sensitive to turf height, Linum the least. Mortality rates of E. nemorosa, Linum, and (especially) E. pseudokerneri were higher during dry periods even over 3 yr of normal rainfall, but Gentianella was not affected. E. pseudokerneri survival was decreased by adding nitrate, and increased by clipping the turf, by adding water and by excluding rabbits Oryctolagus cuniculus; E. pseudokerneri fecundity was increased by excluding rabbits and by adding phosphate; and Linum survival and fecundity were increased by regular applications of snail poison. -from Author

dc:title: Growth, death and size distribution change in an Impatiens pallida population
dc:creator: Thomas S.
dc:description: Growth and fate of individual plants in a natural self-thinning stand of Impatiens pallida located along a disturbed forest edge in SE Pennsylvania were followed from canopy closure to onset of flowering. Mortality in the primary study population was 25%. Lodging was an important cause of death. Smaller plants were more likely to lodge and to suffer herbivore damage. Lodging, independent of plant size, accounted for 16% of mortality; effects of herbivory on mortality (independent of plant size) were not significant, however. Death caused by lodging in a natural self-thinning population supports the hypothesis that biomechanical constraints may have substantial effects on self-thinning relationships and patterns of size structure change in herbaceous plant populations. A decrease in above-ground biomass occurred in 21% of surviving plants in the main study population, but 88% of the surviving plants displaying negative growth flowered by the end of the study. Growth curves were approximately linear over the course of the study period. Survival of plants with negative growth affects the function relating biomass (B) to density (D) and the function relating size inequality to mean plant mass over the course of self-thinning. Had these plants died during the study period, the observed log B-log D slope (-1.73) would have been very close to the mean thinning slope observed across many species (-0.85). Because many non-growing and shrinking plants survived, size inequality did not decrease during self-thinning. -from Authors

dc:title: Large niche overlaps among coexisting plant species in a limestone grassland community
dc:creator: Mahdi A.
dc:description: Data are given on the niches of 8 perennial plant species which occurred commonly in a species-rich limestone grassland. The niche axes were: phenology of above-ground growth and flowering over a 5 month growing season, together with soil depth, pH and levels of available N, P and K, in samples taken at the end of the season. There was little separation of the species on any single niche axis, nor could the species be separated in 6-dimensional niche space. An attempt to separate the species on a resource-ratio gradient of N/P was also unsuccessful. Separation in niche space is unlikely to make a major contribution to coexistence in this community. Investigation of models which permit coexistence in the absence of niche differentiation could prove more fruitful. -from Authors

dc:title: Impact of insect predation on ovule survivorship in Eucalyptus baxteri
dc:creator: Andersen A.
dc:description: Insect predation is a major factor influencing ovule survivorship throughout ovule development in Eucalyptus baxteri in SE Australia. Buds of E. baxteri are produced over summer, and flowering occurs two summers later. One cohort of buds was heavily galled, and <20% flowered. Galling appeared to have adverse effects on the proportion of surviving buds flowering and on the proportion of flowers maturing fruit. Mortality of the previous cohort of buds, which was not galled, and also high, but was apparently caused by low water availability. The proportion of flowers maturing fruit was c30% in both cohorts. At this stage total ovule mortality was at least 95%. The woody fruits mature late in the year following flowering and many persist unopened for several years. Pre-dispersal insect seed predators reduced seed production by at least 70% due primarily to their effects on seed/ovule ratios and on seed viability, and seed-harvesting ants destroyed about 90% of dispersed seeds. The proportion of ovules that became viable seeds available for germination was less than 0.2%. -from Author

dc:title: Demography of short-lived plants in chalk grassland. I. Life cycle variation in annuals and strict biennials
dc:creator: Kelly D.
dc:description: Detailed demographic observations were made on 3 hemiparasitic summer annuals (Euphrasia pseudokerneri, E. nemorosa, Rhinanthus minor) and 2 strict biennials (Linum catharticum, Gentianella amarella) at 3 chalk grassland sites in SE England. All species flowered in the autumn and germinated in the spring. Variation over 3 yr in exact time of germination was correlated with temperature in E. pseudokerneri and Gentianella. Linum germinated at the same time every year, even at sites in different counties; daylength may be a controlling factor. In 1981, early-germinating seedlings had lower survival to flowering in Linum and Gentianella, but in E. pseudokerneri germination date had no effect on survival. In summer 1980, both biennials had a sizeable seed bank (600-2500 m-2), but E. pseudokerneri had virtually none. For all 3 species, most seeds which germinate apparently do so in the first after seedfall. In the field, 14% of seeds sown in autumn 1980 germinated the following spring for Euphrasia, 24% for Linum and 30% for Gentianella. Survival from germination to flowering varied significantly between years by as much as 30-fold. Survival to flowering ranged from 43% to 0.8% in the annuals and from 12% to 6% in the biennials. Many flowering plants (up to 38%) and many flowers (up to 46%) set no seed. Seed outputs per fruiting plant were very low (10-25 for the Euphrasia spp. and Linum, and 30-90 for Rhinanthus and Gentianella). -from Author

dc:title: Changes over twenty-one years in the Kolombangara rain forests
dc:creator: Whitmore T.
dc:description: The 12 dominant canopy-top tree species have differing requirements of canopy disturbance for regeneration, and can be given a pioneer index on the scale 1-4. The pioneer index of the forests as a whole fell by 0.21 during 21.2 yr study, ie disturbance was not sufficient to maintain their initial composition. Individual forest types differed from the mean and within the types the component plots differed from one another, in percentage canopy disturbance, in pioneer index and in gains and losses to individual species. Usually, but not always, extensive canopy disturbance was followed by an increase in tree numbers of species with a high pioneer index. Results show strong spatial and temporal differences in population size and turnover of species and in extent of canopy disturbance; and that generalizations on forest species composition and its change with time are highly dependent on timescale and space scale. -from Author

dc:title: Macro- and microalgal production within a Nitella opaca bed in Lake Thingvallavatn, Iceland
dc:creator: Kairesalo T.
dc:description: Nitella opaca forms a dense bed at a depth of 10-18 m in Lake Thingvallavatn. In 1985 Nitella started growth in early May and achieved maximum height (70-80 cm) and biomass (up to 170 g dry wt m-2, or c50 g C m-2) in October. During November and December the macroalgae collapsed and many of the thalli became detached. During May-September average Nitella biomass accumulation was 153Â±10 (SE) mg C m-2 day-1 at a depth of 10-16 m. Measurements of O2 exchange yielded distinctly higher community production rates than did the 14C-method, possibly due to recycling of 14CO2. Field measurements of 14C-fixation showed that during July-September 40-78% of the total primary production of the Nitella community was attributable to epiphytic (+ epipelic) and planktonic microalgae (mainly diatoms). Microalgal production is sufficient to sustain the rich benthic fauna living among Nitella thalli. -from Authors

dc:title: Root morphology and aerenchyma formation as indicators of the flood- tolerance of Rumex species
dc:creator: Laan P.
dc:description: Rumex species are zoned along a gradient of elevation in the river ecosystem in The Netherlands; R. thyrsiflorus, R. acetosa, R. obtusifolius, R. crispus, R. conglomeratus and R. maritimus were flooded to identify adaptive features. Most Rumex species have a tap-root from which the laterals originate. As a response to flooding, new laterals are formed. Number, place of origin, growth direction and formation rate of new laterals differed between the species. Number and formation rate of new roots were associated with the elevational distribution of the species: as a response to flooding, low-elevation species formed more new roots, and faster, than high-elevation species. The high-elevation species had root porosity values <10%; intermediate- and low-elevation species had values >10%. Schizogenous aerenchyma was constitutively formed by the low-elevation and flood-tolerant R. maritimus, and not by the high-elevation and flood-intolerant R. thyrsiflorus. In the intermediate-elevation R. crispus it was induced in stagnant hypoxic solution cultures. Development of aerenchyma in the new roots is the main determinant in the flood-tolerance of Rumex species. -from Authors

dc:title: Secondary dispersal of seed across snow in Betula lenta, a gap- colonizing tree species
dc:creator: Matlack G.
dc:description: Seed was released preferentially on days with high winds and below-freezing temperatures. Catkins held in experimental environments released seed at low humidity, regardless of temperature. Through secondary dispersal across a snow surface, seeds in a natural population were distributed over an area 3.3 times greater than the area covered by aerial dispersal alone. Large numbers of seeds accumulated in indentations in the snow, and in shallow depressions corresponding to the bases of uprooted trees. Very few seeds were deposited on the smooth snow surface. Daily control of seed release during an autumn-winter dispersal period appears to promote long-range secondary dispersal by wind across a snow surface. Through this mechanism, "passive' dispersal by wind produces non-random, aggregated seed distributions, and increases the chances of seeds arriving in suitable regeneration sites. -from Author

dc:title: Patterns of nutrient immobilization and release in decomposing forest litter in Central Himalaya, India
dc:creator: Upadhyay V.
dc:description: Decomposition of leaf litter from 10 woody species was studied using litter bags incubated for 2 yr in 5 forest ecosystems, and Quercus leucotrichophora leaf litter was placed in each forest site to provide uniform substrate quality. Annual weight loss ranged from 47-100% among species. Differences between sites and species were significant. Most species exhibited 2 phases in their nutrient dynamics, a net immobilization phase followed by a net release phase. Net immobilization of N and P occurred in all litter species except Mallotus philippensis, Lyonia ovalifolia and Quercus leucotrichophora, while Ca and K exhibited only a release phase except in Pinus roxburghii and Myrica esculenta, where net immobilization of Ca occurred for a short period. The periods of net immobilization of various nutrients overlapped to a considerable extent. Material with higher initial C:nutrient ratios had a longer duration of immobilization and, in turn, a slower release phase. The critical C:N ratio (at which net release of N occurred), varied from 15:1 to 55:1. Species having higher N contents (1.20-3.04%) had higher weight loss rates. Species having >17% initial lignin accumulated more N. Mean annual temperature, altitude and lignin content were the principal regulating factors for weight loss and nutrient mineralization. -from Authors

dc:title: Species interactions in a successional grassland. I. Seed rain and seedling recruitment
dc:creator: Peart D.
dc:description: Seed rain and recruitment for the 5 most abundant species of grasses were quantified in a California coastal grassland undergoing succession after release from sheep grazing. Species distributions were very patchy: 4 patch types accounted for c95% of total cover. Three patch types ("perennial patches') were dominated, respectively, by 1 of 3 species of perennial grasses, Anthoxanthum odoratum, Holcus lanatus or Deschampsia holciformis. "Annual patches' were dominated by annual grasses, including the most abundant annual Vulpia bromoides, the perennial grass Rytidosperma pilosum and forbs. Species not present in patches contributed little to the seed rain and nothing to recruitment in the interiors of those patches. Species differed significantly in the densities of their seed rain in the patches they dominated, ranging from 2300 m-2 for R. pilosum to 82 300 m-2 for H. lanatus. Density of seed rain was patchy on all spatial scales examined (from cm to km), but was not significantly correlated with densities of recruits on any scale for the perennial species. However, V. bromoides recruitment correlated positively with the density of its seed rain on small spatial scales (up to 1 m2) in annual patches. The poor relationship between seed rain and recruitment for the perennials probably reflects the over-riding importance of adult interference as an influence on seedling establishment in the perennial vegetation. A. odoratum has relatively high recruitment (30 m-2) in the patches it dominated. Other perennials had very low recruitment in their own stands (less than 5 m-2). V. bromoides had the highest recruitment (904 m-2) in annual patches. -from Author

dc:title: Foliage-crown development and interaction in Quercus gilva and Q. acuta
dc:creator: Koike F.
dc:description: The mechanisms of foliage-crown development and crown-to-crown interactions mediated by light conditions were measured in evergreen oak trees. Three crowns were expressed in terms of a spatial foliage-density distribution, and the coarse of the interactions was considered as a long-term change of this distribution in each crown. The critical light level, below which shoot population could not be maintained, was c30% of full light in Q. acuta and c10% in Q. gilva. Actual light intensity under foliage-crowns of both species was less than that of their critical light level, due to active multiplication of foliage at the canopy surface and light interception by old leaves. The process of crown development was described mathematically as changes in the spatial distribution of foliage density, taking into account light conditions. Such changes were estimated from the leaf area of current-year's shoots, leaf survivorship and shoot population dynamics (ie yearly changes in the spatial distribution of shoot population density). All parameters in this model were obtained from actual crowns. The development of interacting foliage-crowns was reproduced by simulation. In actual foliage-crowns, dense foliage was found in the upper and peripheral parts of the total canopy composed of both crowns, and foliage density was low at the lower side. -from Author

dc:title: Responses of Mediterranean grassland plants to grazing and protection
dc:creator: Noy-Meir I.
dc:description: Of the 73 most common species in an Israeli grassland, 49 showed responses to grazing by cattle that were largely consistent over sites, being either significantly more abundant on the more protected side, significantly more abundant on the more grazed side, or not significantly different. The remaining 24 species were inconsistent, being significantly more abundant on the protected side in some sites and on the grazed side in others. Of the inconsistent species, 14 showed a pattern of responses over sites that could be explained by a unimodal response to grazing intensity, with an optimum at intensities between the extremes of complete protection and very heavy continuous grazing. Perennial species with long growing seasons were somewhat more frequent among protection increasers, and their total cover greater in protected grassland. Grazing responses was strongly and significantly associated with plant growths form: protection increasers were mostly tall erect plants; grazing increasers mostly small, prostrate or rosette plants; and species with intermediate responses mostly erect plants of medium height. Ungrazed grassland was dominated (60-80% cover) by tall perennials and tall, annual grasses. Under light to moderate grazing their cover decreased to the benefit of annuals of a wide range of growth forms and families; of those, under heavy grazing, small and prostrate annuals, rosette crucifers and thistles remained abundant. Responses to grazing can be explained best by the opening of establishment gaps in the closed sward of foliage and mulch maintained by the dominants. At moderate to heavy grazing the vertical differential defoliation gradient imposed by cattle, particularly early in the growing season, becomes the major mechanism of grassland change. -from Authors

dc:title: Variation in the impact of insect herbivory on Trifolium pratense through early plant succession
dc:creator: Gange A.
dc:description: Under reduced levels of insect herbivory, plants grew taller and produced more leaves while individual leaf area was unchanged. Herbivory resulted in a reduction in plant size (assessed by total leaf area) and an increase in size variability (measured by the coefficient of variation). Number of seed heads per plant and individual seed weight were reduced by herbivory. There was no difference in seed viability, but more plants became established from seeds produced by insecticide-treated plants. In 2 of 3 communities, herbivory significantly reduced plant survivorship, due to the death of small individuals. -from Authors

dc:title: Species interactions in a successional grassland. II. Colonization of vegetated sites
dc:creator: Peart D.
dc:description: Colonization and inhibition abilties were quantified and compared in a patchy Californian grassland community. The 4 most abundant perennial species, Anthoxanthum odoratum, Holcus lanatus, Deschampsia holciformis and Rytidosperma pilosum, differed greatly in colonizing ability, as measured by survival, growth and reproduction. All perennial species effectively inhibited colonization of their stands, but annual vegetation could be colonized by Anthoxanthum and to a lesser degree by Holcus. Species differences in colonizing ability depended in part on their different densities of seed rain, but there were major differences in intrinsic, per-seed colonizing ability as well. Species differences in inhibition ability could be explained by above-ground biomass alone; intrinsic differences among species in their per-unit biomass inhibition effects were not important. -from Author

dc:title: Seed banks, fire season, safe sites and seedling recruitment in five co-occurring Banksia species
dc:creator: Enright N.
dc:description: Quantity of seed stored in the canopy of 5 co-occurring Banksia species varied by nearly 2 orders of magnitude. The 3 species which resprout vegetatively after fire, produced less seeds and retained smaller seed banks than 2 non-sprouting species. Contiguous patches of scrub-heath were burned in spring and autumn. The spring fire was cooler, and both sets of seed released subsequently did not germinate until the following (common) winter. Rate of seed release was higher after the autumn fire. The non-sprouting species released more seeds after each fire and yielded more seedlings per parent than the resprouting species. Percentage (field) germination of the non-sprouters was not consistently different from that of the resprouters. Seeds exposed on the soil surface during summer soon lost viability compared with buried seeds. The large number of seedlings established up to 8 months after the spring fire resulted from many seeds escaping exposure by dispersal into litter-covered "safe' sites. Although litter microsites covered only 30% of the ground surface after the spring burn, they accounted for 80% of seedlings both before and after the summer drought. Litter microsites covered only 14% of the autumn-burned site but accounted for 60% of seedlings before summer and 40% after summer, suggesting density-dependent thinning of seedlings. The autumn-burned site supported more than twice the density of seedlings than the spring-burned site by the end of the 1st winter. Summer mortality of seedlings was 32% in the spring-burned site and 65% in the autumn-burned site, equalizing the seedling:parent ratio at both sites. Net recruitment of 1-yr-old seedlings varied from 0 for 2 resprouters to >100 per parent for a non-sprouter. -Authors

dc:title: Seed dispersal of four sympatric grassland annual species of Erodium
dc:creator: Stamp N.
dc:description: Four sympatric Erodium (Geraniaceae) species explosively discharged their awned fruits (diaspores), which then dispersed further and buried themselves by hygroscopic movements. Without neighbouring plants the fruits were thrown up to 1 m, but this was reduced to a minimum of 0.3 m by contacting neighbours (the usual situation). The largest diaspores (E. botrys) rarely buried themselves, regardless of substrate or time of exposure to water. In the field, the rate of diaspore burial declined throughout the season. The 2 larger diaspores (E. botrys, E. brachycarpum buried themselves more often than the smaller diaspores (E. cicutarium, E. moschatum); large numbers of diaspores (of both sizes) failed to bury themselves and thus remained on the soil surface over the summer months. Percentage germination was higher when diaspores were buried. With normal watering, seedling biomass was greater for those in bare soil compared to those in straw-littered soil. However, under drought conditions, seedlings in the straw-littered soil were larger than those in bare soil.
